div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,135] ALEXANDRIA, TUESDAY, FEBURARY 28, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Pagnon's Hotels.
div.p: Catarct Hotel, Assouan.

This most popular hotel on the Upper Nile has recently been enlarged by the addition of 65 rooms and accomodates guests. Great dining hall, lifts, tennis court and garden. On the south side overlooking the river. Billard room and bar., electric light throughout. Anglican Church within a few minutes of the Hotel grounds.

Grand Hotel, Assouan.-Under the same management. Beautifully situated on river. Accommodates 90 guests. Moderate terms. Entirely rebuilt since the fire, and fitted throughout in the most modern style. Beuatiful terrace overlooking river. Electric light throughout.

TUESDAY, FEBURARY 28, 1905.

div.head: THE WAR
div.p: The telegrams of the recent fighting tend to show that another great battle has begun, but whether this battle will be decisive or not can hardly be foreseen. It may very well be a repetition of that of the Sha-ho, a long wrestle in which both adversaries may wear themselves out until they must pause to rest before renewing the encounter. Yet, the Russian game is the more desperate, for if General Kuropatkin again fails to drive back the Japanese, his failure must recoil on the Government of Russia, and increase the bitterness of the population against its masters. If be should push back the Japanese, he will only drive them to strong positions in which they can renew their defence. Bat if Marshal Oyama should now be able to break the Russian resistance

div.head: Sunlight
div.p: A great economiser and saver of time, health, and strength.
Laundry worries went out of woman's life when Sunlight Soap came into it.
It is the purest Soap going.
Soap

either by piercing his enemy’s front or by turning a flank, and thereby compel another Russian retreat, the effect on Russia will be disastrous. The principle that a. despotic Power must seek to maintain itself at home by military successes abroad is as old as Plato, and accounts for much of Russia’s recent foreign policy. But a despotism after defeat usually finds the foundations of its power at home shaken. That a nation may have civil war at home, and yet be successful in its wars abroad, is proved by many instances, among which may be reckoned both the Civil War or Great Rebellion in England, and the wars of the French Revolution. But it has usually been the popular forces engaged in the domestic struggle against absolutism which have been successful against foreign foes, for in such cases the domestic struggle has led to the triumph of the national principle, the source of strength in conflict with the foreigner. The case of an absolute Government suc- cessful both in repression at home and in aggression abroad is not so easy to find. At any rate, in the battle which has now begun in the country between Mukden and Liao-yang the Russian Army is fighting to save the prin- ciple of absolutism in Russia, and to keep the yoke on the necks of the Russian people. The Japanese Army is fighting for the freedom of Japan, and its victory would contribute greatly to the freedom of the Russian people. Thus, as we have all along believed, Japan is in this war the representative of all that the Western World holds dear, and Russia is the champion of the Oriental conception of absolutism. If the war is the conflict of East against West, it is Japan that in the spiritual, as distinct from the geographical, sense represents the West.

div.head: INSURRECTION IN YEMEN.
div.p: TROOPS DESERTING.
Jeddah, February 27.

Almost the whole of Yemen south of Sana is in a state of insurrection. Two towns are in the Hands of the insurgents, who are increasing in number. It is difficult to send reinforce- ments, and, moreover, the troops are deserting. (Reuter.)

div.head: GERMAN NAVY ESTIMATES.
div.p: REDUCED BY 3,000,000 MARKS.
Berlin, February 27.
The Reichstag has reduced the Navy Estimates by over 8,000,000 marks. The items rejected include a gunboat for Asia, mentioned on the 25th November last, (Reuter.)

div.head: The War
div.p: BATTLE OF BERESNEFF
RUSSIAN MAIN DEFENCES THREATENED.
CONTINUED FIGHTING.

London, February 27. The accounts of the fighting in Manchuria are of the most meagre description, and are still exclusively from Russian sources. They indicate that the engagement at Beresneff was the beginning of a great battle, and part of a general Japanese movement against the Russian left flank. Beresneff Hill was one of the strongest of several fortified heights forming the position of Tsing-khe-cheng, situated on the south slope of the Taling mountains, 18 miles south west of Shin-King, and barring the way to the passes leading to Fu-Shun, - where Kuropatkin has his centre.

Reuter’s correspondent with General Kuro-patkin states that the Japanese have captured the outlying positions and now threaten the Russian main defences. Up to now, the battle has been fought in a blustering snowstorm. (R.)

St. Petersburg, February 27. Fighting continues in the neighbourhood of Tsing-khe-cheng. It is believed that General Nogi is vigorously employing the guns which served in the siege of Fort Arthur. (Havas.

St. Petersburg, February 27. General Kuropatkin states that the Japanese have turned both flanks of a Russian force at Tsing- khe-cheng. He vaguely reports Japanese attacks at several other points, some of which have apparently been successful, and others repulsed. (Reuter.)
DESPATCH OF REINFORCEMENTS.

London, February 27. The "Times” learns from St Petersburg that the transport of troops to the front has been greatly delayed all the winter. None of the reinforcements despatched during December will reach Kuropatkin before next April. (Reuter.)
PRUSSIAN PRINCE DEPARTS.
Berlin, February 27. Prince Friedric Leopold of Prussia has started for the Far East via Genoa. (Reuter.)

div.head: GENERAL STOESSEL
div.p: GOING TO ST. PETERSBURG.
Moscow, February 25. General Stoessel has been cordially received by the authorities. Ho proceeds to St. Petersburg on Wednesday, afterwards returning here, where he will make a prolonged stay. (R)

div.head: THIRD BALTIC FLEET.
div.p: PASSED CHERBOURG.
Cherbourg, February 27. The third Russian squadron has passed.(H.)

div.head: NORTH SEA REPORT.
div.p: LONDON PRESS OPINION.

London, February 27. The papers, commenting on the text of the North Sea report, consider that it is substantially in favor of Britain. The wording shows the Admirals to bo skilled diplomatists. The press declares that the example set before the world as regards the method of settling differences makes the Commission an epoch-marking one. (Reuter.)

div.head: DEATH OF GUY BOOTHBY.
div.p: London, February 27. Mr. Guy Newell Boothby, the novelist, dead. (Reuter.)

Guy Boothby was born at Adelaide, S. Australia, on the 13th October, 1867. His father was a member of the House of Assembly, and his grandfather was Mr. Justice Boothby. He was educated at Salisbury. In 1891 he crossed Australia from North to South, and he also travelled in the East. Among the works that have made bis name famous novelist may be mentioned- “The Marriage of Esther” (1895), “Dr. Nikola" (1896). “Across the world for a Wife" (1898), “Pharos the Egyptian’’ (1899), “Dr. Nikola’s Experi ment" (1899), “A Millionaire's Love Story” (1901). He was fond of riding, driving,cycling, collecting live fish from all countries, and breeding prize dogs, horses, and cattle.

div.head: Windsor Hotel
div.p: Largest 1st class and most comfortable Hotel in Alexandria. Facing the new Central position. Under English management.

div.head: SITUATION IN RUSSIA.
div.p: POLICE STRIKE FEARED

St. Petersburg, February 27. In order to ensure the railway service, the Government has commanded that all railway-men in the Empire are to be treated as soldiers, and subjected to martial law. (Reuter.)
Warsaw, February 27. Every policeman is now accompanied by a soldier as the authorities fear a police strike. (Reuter.)
Charleroi, February 27. The strike is extending in the Borinage. (Havas.)
RELEASE OF MAXIM GORKI.
St. Petersburg, February 27. Maxim Gorki has been released. ( Havas.)

div.head: Local and General
div.p: Cairo Full.—About 300 visitors arrived at Cairo last night from the S.S. “Moltke” and greatly taxed the accommodation of the, hotels.
Fervent Loyalty.—Tbe subscription started by the “Lewa” for the construction of the Turkish man-of-war has only attained L.E.315, although it has been open for many months.

Khartoum Garrison—The party of the 2nd Battalion Rifle Brigade, consisting of three officers and 91 non commissioned officers and men, will leave Cairo at 8 p.m. to-morrow for Shellal, en route to Khartoum.

Suez Canal.— On the 23rd inst. 12 vessels passed through the Canal, 4 of which were British, 4 German, 2 Russian, 1 Australian, 1 French, the receipts lor the day being frs. 350,462.63. The total receipts from 1st inst. amounted to frs. 8,040,690.79.

The Cairo Italian Benevolent Society’s annual ball will take place in the specially constructed ball-room in the Esbekieh Gardens on Friday next. The function promises to be a great success, and will be under the patronage of the Italian Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General.

P.W.D. Contracts. — The contract for the construction of a markaz at Damanhour has been given to Ahmed Abou Youssef, the price being L.E. 4,429. Messrs. G. Kaul & Co. have secured the contract for the building of an annexe to the parcel post office at Alexandria, the price of L.E.2,575.

Homeward Bound.—Visitors to Egypt will a short time (all too soon!) be contemplating the homeward journey, and to those we have no hesitation in recommending the vessels of the White Star Line, which reach Naples from Alexandria in something less than three days on their way to America. The immediate sailings are “Canopic'(13,000tons). March 9 ; ‘Republic” (15,400 tons),March 16; “Romanic" (11,400 tons), March 30 ; and the fares from Alexandria are £10 and upwards. Bookings be effected at the White Star agents in Alexandria, Messrs. J. Ross and Co., and at Cook's tourist offices in Cairo.

M.C.L. School for the Blind.—A bazaar in aid of the funds of the M.C.L Industrial School for the Blind will be held on Tuesday, 14th March, from 3 to 6 p.m., in the premises of the school. The new building stands on the ground known as the Cicolanui gardens. It is satisfactory to find that the sale of basket-work made at the school realised during 1904 a little over £200, a steady increase on former years. Among other attrac-at the bazaar will be the performance of the pretty little play, "Beauty and the Beast,” by the pupils of Mrs. Anastas. Many pretty and useful articles, including verandah chairs and all kinds of basket-work, will be for sale.

Helouan.—We are pleased to hear that the Egyptian Cavalry Band has been again engaged to play on Sundays in the kiosk of the public park at Helouan. The public are indebted lor this pleasure to the thoughtfulness of the Delta Light Railway Co. and the energetic committee of the Helouan Sporting Club. The band has for the past two months been Khartoum for the festivities in connection with the visit of H.R.H. the Duke of Connaught, hence its absence up to now. The town of Helouan owes much to the H.S.C. for having infused fresh life into the district. Its numerous race meetings have given enjoyment to thousands, and have been the means of bringing a large influx of visitors and residents to Helouan who otherwise would never have seen this delightful health resort The next and last race meeting of this season will take place Saturday, 11th March.

div.head: Tyrol.
div.p: Weissenstein Castle 3410 ft. First-class private hotel near Windisch-Matrei; Station, Lienz (resehed from Venice or Trieste). Bracing air. Good Mountaineering centre. Tennis. Fishing. Best June, September. Apply Propreitor

div.head: THE ROYAL BETROTHAL.
div.p: PRINCE GIVES BALL & RECEPTION.

H.R.H. Prince Gustavus Adolphus of Sweden and Norway gave a ball and reception yesterday evening at the Ghezireh Palace Hotel in honor of his betrothal to H.R.H. Princess Margaret of Connaught The ball-room divided into two pans, half for the dance itself and half for the reception, and the gallery in Moorish style was converted into a smoking-room. The guests numbered over 140, and included the Duke and Duchess of Connaught, Princesses Margaret and Victoria Patricia of Connaught, and their suite, H. H. Prince Mohamed Aly, all the Diplomatic representatives of the Powers, the Ministers, Major-General, Mrs. and Miss Slade, and the Headquarters Staff of the Army of Occupation and of the Egyptian Army.
Dancing lasted till a late hour, the coup d'œil being superb. Supper was served at separate tables at 11.45, and all the arrangements were carried out with the utmost precision and success.
THE KHEDIVE.

H. H. the Khedive passed the greater part of yesterday at Abdeen Palace, where he gave audience to M. Gennadis, who presented M. P. Psycha, Secretary, and M. E. Panas, dragoman , to the Hellenic Agency.

The Shah has conferred on his Highness the Grand Cordon of the Order of "Timthali Humayuni" (Imperial Portrait). The patent and insignia of the Order will be handed to his Highness shortly at Abdeen Palace by Mirza Ali Askhar Khan, Persian Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General.
KHEDIVE’S NEW PALACE.

M. Korber, the well-known Genevese architect has been charged by the Khedive with the preparation of plans for the palace which he wishes to bo erected on the shores of the Bosphorus. The building will be on magnificent scale, and is intended to be used as a summer residence.

M. Korber leaves Geneva shortly for Cairo to receive his final instructions. It is stated that the Sultan is greatly pleased with the scheme, which will necessitate an outlay of several million francs.
RETURN OF PILGRIMS.
A telegram from Mecca states that the Egyptian pilgrims are leaving the Holy City to-day. The health of all is satisfactory.
EGYPTIAN ARMY.
Local Miralai J. J. Asser Bey, Acting. Secretary General, Sudan Government, has been promoted to the rank of Miralai.

Lieutenant K. E. Edgeworth, Royal Engineers, having reported his arrival in Egypt from England, has been taken on the strength of the Egyptian Army, with the rank of Bim-bashi. Ho has been posted to the Department of Works.
El Bimbashi E. E. Meyricke, Sudan Government, is struck off the strength of the Egyptian Army.
abbas helmy THEATRE.
LAST APPEARANCE OF BELLINCIONI.
We may remind our readers that Signora Bellincioni makes her final appearance at Alexandria this evening in Giordano’s Fedora, in which the great artiste is absolutely incomparable.

Sunday night’s performance of La Boheme was remarkable for the splendid acting and singing of Signora Béllihcioni. Never has Alexandria seen so natural a Mimi as was ; she whs in every way delightful, and the public applauded her performance with a whole-heartedness which was unmistakeable. Of the other artistes, Sig. Tomisani, as Rodolfo, was the most conspicuous, but the performance as a whole was not up to the previous productions in which Signors Bellincioni has taken part The staging of the opera left a good deal to be desired, and the man in charge of the lighting arrangements showed a lack of the sense of the artistic which rendered the first act ludicrous. So far as staging is concerned we can promise those attending to-night’s performance of Fedora a great treat ; in this respect, if not in every other respect as well, it is the best opera staged by the company.

G. AQUILINA, Proprieter.

div.head: DUKE OF CONNAUGHT'S VISIT.
div.p: ARRANGEMENTS FOR TO-MORROW.
The Duke and Duchess of Connaught, with the Princesses and Sir William Garstin, visited the Delta Barrage on Saturday morning.

As announced yesterday, the Royal party will leave Cairo for Alexandria at 2 p.m. to-day, and will arrive at the Arsenal wharf about 6 o'clock, when they will immediately proceed on board H.M.S. “Essex," which has been lying in the harbour since Sunday.

To-morrow, the Duke of Connaught will hold a thorough inspection of the Alexandria garrison. He will first proceed to Mustapha and inspect the 2nd Battalion R. Berkshire Regiment and all the other units there. After lunching with the officers of the regiment, he will proceed to Kom el-Dik to inspect the Royal Malta Artillery, and will then go to Ras el-Tin to inspect the hospital.

“Loyalist” writes: — It seems a strange thing to me, as a loyal subject of his Majesty King Edward VII., that nothing has been done to give the British colony, which is now a very numerous one, a chance of seeing their King's Royal brother and his august family passing through Alexandria, it has, however, come to. my knowledge that H. R. H. the Duke of Connaught, as Inspector General of H. M.’s Forces, will be passing through the principal streets of Alexandria on his way to the Mustapha barracks at about 10 a.m. to-morrow. This is, however, a very bad hour for business men, but if they are loyally disposed they could get a good view of the Royal party on their return to town and on the way to the Citadel of Kom-el-Dik, which is to be inspected at 2.45 p.m. The open space at the top of Rosetta-road would be an excellent coign of vantage, as well as the glacis at each side, beyond what was the moat outside the city. Thinking that there might be many British subjects desirous perhaps for the first time in their life of testifying to their loyal feelings in some way, however modest, I have ventured to point out through the medium of the columns of your paper the only way left to them of giving their Royalties a hearty cheer en passant.

div.head: SANIEH GIRLS’ SCHOOL
div.p: VISIT OF DUCHESS OF CONNAUGHT.

On Saturday afternoon her Royal Highness the Duchess of Connaught and the Countess of Cromer visited the Sauieh Girls’ School and Training College for Teachers, Cairo, in the spacious new buildings in the Nasrieh quarter to which the School and Training College have recently been transferred. The Primary School is attended 154 girls, of whom 148 are Mohamedans, and in the Training College there are 15 students, all of whom have obtained the Primary Education certificate, and of whom 12 are Mohamedans. All the students in the Training College are in residence, and in the Primary School there are 117 day-boarders and 37 full boarders. In the Primary School all the girls are paying pupils', but in the Training College each student receives a scholarship of L.E.24 per annum as well as their education and board free of charge.

Her Royal Highness inspected the Kindergarten and some of the five classes of the Primary School, and heard lessons in English grammar and reading, given by a trained Egyptian mistress, and also saw some of the pupils’ needlework. Her Royal Highness then visited the three classes of the Training College lor Teachers, hearing lessons in pedagogy, arithmetic, and geography, given by three of the English members of the staff. The art-room, where the students in training learn to illustrate their lessons by drawing, was also Inspected, as well as the airy dormitories, entirely refurnished by Messrs. Maple & Co., and the bath-rooms.

The Countess of Cromer presented to her Royal Highness several members of the staff, among whom arc seven Egyptian women teachers, five of whom received their professional training in the College, and 6 English.
Theannual exhibition of embroideries and of drill, to which the leading lady-residents in Cairo have been invited, will be held in the school on Wednesday next

div.head: A. L. M. & D. S.
div.p: The grand concert which is to take place to-morrow evening at the New Khedivial Hotel in the large ballroom bids fair to be the best amateur performance of the season. With such names as Mme. Briend, Mme. Haddad, Dr. Keller, and Mr. Afendoulis on the programme, one may well say the committed has prepared a musical fare for Princes. The Choral Union has prepared some part songs under the able baton of Mr. W. Sarjeant which will appeal to the British colony ; but the amateur orchestra will not be ready on this occasion. It will however, take part in the oratorio ("The Holy City," by Gaul). We append the programme for to-morrow night:Part 1.-1. Glee, Hail Smiling Morn (Spof- forth), members of the Choral Union ; 2. Song Rondel de l'Adieu (De Lara), Dr. Keller ; Pianoforte solo : (a) Impromptu (Rubinstein) (b) Le Rossignol (Lizst), Mme. Haddad ; 4. Violin solo, Airs Hongrois (Tirindelli), Mr. Afendoulis. accompanied by Mme. Foscolo ; 5. Air de Chimène, from Le Cid (Massenet), Mme. Briend ; 6. Madrigal, Down in a Flow'ry Dale (Festa), members of the Choral Union. Part II.—1. Part song, Gipsy Life (Schu-of the Choral Union ; 2. Violin solo;(a)Madrigale(Simonetti), (b)Serenata Napolitana(Scambati), Mr. Afendoulis; 3. Chansons:(a)L'Attende(Saint-Saens)(b) Si mes vers d'vaient des ailes (Reynald Hahn). Mme. Briend : 4. Pianoforte solo, Rhapsodie Hongroise No. 12 (Lizst), Mme. Haddad ; 5. Song, Serenata (Mario Costa), Dr. Keller ; 8. song,. When Evening's Twilight (Hatton), then of Choral Union,

div.head: THE LATE HAICALIS PASHA.
div.p: FUNERAL CEREMONY.

The funeral of Dr. Haicalis Pasha took place yesterday afternoon. The procession left the residence of the deceased in Sesostris-street shortly after four o’clock, and was headed by a squadron of mounted police and a large number of janissaries from the various consulates. Then came the wreaths, which were magnificent in form and variety and filled about a dozen carriages. These floral tributes were headed by two very large wreaths carried by bearers which were sent by the Mohamed Aly Club and the “Egyptian Gazette." A long train of high ecclesiastic of the Greek-Orthodox Church came next, preceding the pall, which was borne by Judge Sandars, of the Mixed Court of Appeal, representing the Bench of. the Mixed Tribunal ; Maltre Cuzzer, batonnier of the Order of Advocates, representing the Bar of the Mixed Courts ; Mr. Emmanuel Benachi, President of the Hellenic Community of Alexandria ; Hafez Mohamed Bey, Sub-Govenor of Alexandria ; Mr. Antoine Saktouris, Hellenic Vice-Consul, and the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette."

After the pall-bearers came Mustapha Effendi Fehmy, of the staff of the “Phare d’Alexandrie," who carried the sword and eleven orders and decorations of the Pasha on a velvet cushion, including the Grand Cordon of the Medjidieh, Commander of the Osmanieh, Chevalier of the Hellenic Order of the Saviour, Commander of the Italian Order of the Holy Sepulchre, and the Chevalier of the French Legion of Honour. The mourners followed, the chief mourners being John Bey Haicalis, the only eon of the Pasha, who was supported by Captain Peirakos Mavromichalis, of the Hellenic Royal Artillery, son-in-law, and Mr. Senes Ruscovich, brother-in-law of the Pasha, Mr. Staffy and John Sofios, and Mr. Scotidis, Hellenic Consul-Ge-neral. The crowd of mourners embraced a very representative assemblage of all the leading members of Alexandrian society. The Khedive, with whose father and grandfather the Pasha had been on terms of the greatest intimacy, had sent instruction) to Mahmoud Pasha Sidky, Governor of Alexandria, to representhim, as his Highness was very grieved at the loss of the editor of a newspaper, with which devotion to the Khediviate has ever been a marked feature.

All the chief members of the Hellenic colony were present, and among others we noticed Mahmoud Pasha Sidky, Governor of Alexandria, Saba Pasha, Postmaster General, M. Girard, French Consul, Baron von Humboldt-Dachrœden, German Consul, Chevalier Puscariu, Austro Hungarian Consul, Baron Acton, Italian Consul, Judge Pangalo, Judge Reizian Bey, Judge Sandars, Judge Eeman, Judge Papa dopoulo. The Egyptian Press was represented by M. Canivet, of “la Reforme," Cavaliere K Debono, of the “Messaggiere Egixiano,” Schmeil Bey, of “Al Bassir,” M. Paul Manse, of "L’Egypte,” Mr. Liazzis, of the “Tachydromos,” Mr. Dikalos, of the “Telegraphos," M. de la garenne, of the “Correspondance Egyptienne,” dr. Braun, of the “Revne de l'Egypte,” M. Constantine Tutungi, of the "Pyramides” and "Al Ahram."

The service, which took place in the Evan-gelismos Cathedral, was conducted by Monsignor Theophanis Moschonas, Metropolitan of Tripoli, assisted by the clergy of the Greek-Orthodox Cathedral, the Patriarchal Church of St. Saba, and the Greek-Orthodox Syrian Church of the Assumption.

At the close of the service an eloquent funeral oration was pronounced by the Hellenic Consul-General at Alexandria. The mortal remains of the Pasha were taken to the chapel of the Greek-Orthodox cemetery, where the interment took place this morning.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL OPERA HOUSE.
div.p: Mefistofele on Saturday night might have been an admirable performance. The orchestra was admirable, no fault could be found with the staging and costumes, and Mr. Walter’s acting was admirable. But there were some terribly weak points in the rendering of an opera which takes rank among all but the v highest, and deserves and demands an infinitely higher standard of singing and acting than, say, Traviata, or even Gounod's Faust. Signora Pinto was not intended for the role. of Marguerite; the delightful playfulness of the garden scene, with its close in a burst of childish half-hysterical laughter, was beyond her reach. She sang with vigour (her voice is powerful enough to fill a larger opera-house than Cairo’s) and with an amazing want of perception of the treatment required in the 2nd act, while the vibrato with which her voice was literally overcharged made it difficult to hear her with patience. In the prison scene she was admirable—the vibrato had almost disappeared, her acting of a part that had become tragic was above the mark, in foot she gave a very good rendering of exactly half of her part and was apparently incapable of doing anything like justice to the rest. M. Walteras Mephistopheles was uneven. He acted admirably, but his voice, though true enough and aided by a good delivery, had not the range or the volume that his role required. His song in the 2nd scene of the 1st act was admirably given: he was at his best there and he acted consistently well. After all his part is desperately difficult ; the Mephistopheles of Gonnod's Faust has nothing bizarre and terrible by comparison with Boito's saturnine and cruel tempter, and M. Walter showed that be had studied the part, and had no intention of giving us Gounod's devil in a slightly different costume. Faust was good ; he sang with taste, never foiled to hit the note, and only wanted volume. He acted very fairly, bat might, have thrown a little more senility into his voice in the 1st act. It was a little startling to detect no difference in the voice of the weary and infirm recluse of the first end the amorons end lusty gallant of the second set.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: H- H. the Khedive has been pleased to confer the 4th class Medjidieh on El Bimbashi A C. Parker, Sudan
Crookshank Pasha was at the Fayoum on Sunday and returns to Cairo to-day from his inspection in Upper Egypt

M. Sarros, Greek Consul at Batum, has been transferred to Port Said, in place of M, Spiliotaki The latter has been appointed Consul at Galatz, to fill the place of M. D. Kymeriti, promoted consul-general at Trieste.
Maitre Albrecht, we hear today, is progressing as favorably can be expected.

Sir Thomas Lapton, who was recently staying in Cairo, arrived quite unexpectedly at Colombo on the 11th inst by the S.S. “Marmora." A telegram announcing bis visit having reached Colombo early on the day, he was met on arrival by Mr. Jeffery, the head of the local branch of Lipton, Ltd. A representative of the “Times of Ceylon" had an interview with Sir Thomas on board the ship, in the coarse of which he stated that he had only come on to Ceylon to look after his tea interests there, and was not “on rubber bent."
Mr. and Mrs. Seed, who arrived a few days ago by the P. and O. S.S. “Arabia," are making a prolonged stay in Egypt They are staying at the Grand Continental Hotel.

The following passengers left Shellal on Sunday by the P. S. “Prince Abbas” ; Mrs. Marram, Miss Fanny Lehr, Mr. Dalborgo, Mr. Mercidi, Mr. John E. Madden, Mias Young, Mrs. Gabriel, Mrs. W. W. div.head: QUESTIONS MUNICIPALE
div.p: Une Petite Revue de l’Annee

Nous avons vu que la Delegation Municipale ne se faisait pas faute de passer outre aux dé cisions de la Commission, lorsque celles-ci no l'intéressaient pas d’une facon toute particulière. Or ce ne sont pas, comme on pourrait le croire, les questions d'ordre public qui passionnent ces messieurs, mais uniquement celles d’ordre tout personnel, tels quo l’adjudication des travaux, le percement des rues dans certains quartiers etc. Aussi les décisions concernant l'intérêt général sont-elles pour la plupart délaissées et jetées au panier.

Pour qu’on ue nous taxe pas d'exagération, noua avons voulu jeter un coup d’oeil rétrospectif sur. l’exercice qui vient de s’écouler et extraire au hasard les principales délibérations de la Commission dont il n’a été tenu aucun compte par la toute puissante Délégation. Cela édifiera les Alexandrins sur la gestion des affaires municipales au lendemain de la réorganisation.

On se rappelle que l’enquête sur les services do la Municipalité prit fin avec la retraite dès Mohamed Bey Saïd, La Commission, pourtant, consciente des abus qui se commettaient dans toutes les branches des services, ordonna la continuation de l’enquête et nomma Abani Bey, pour remplacer Mob. Bey Saïd. Mais la Délégation ne lanca plus de convocations et se fit ainsi la complice des concussionnaires. (20 janvier 1904).

Le danger que présentent les fils électriques suspendus sur nos têtes a été prévu par nos édiles. Des experts ont été chargés par eux de rédiger un rapport. Mais la Délégation n’y a donné aucune suite (20 janvier 1904).

On sait que la loi électorale est défectueuse sous bien des rapports. Les efforts tentés par. divers membres pour l’améliorer ont abouti à une réforme votée par la Commission ; mais la Délégation a passé outre (3 février 1904).
Le 30 mars la Commission émet le vœu auprès du Gouvernement de voir modifier le règlement provisoire instituant le conseil du Tanzim. Aucune suite n'est donnée h cette décision.

S. E. Boghos Pacha Nubar offre de construire à ses frais une fontaine publique monumentale gratuite dans un des quartiers indigenes les plus populeux d’Alexandrie. Cette offre est acceptée par la Commission, mais la Délégation, qui se trémousse lorsqu’il s agit de gaspiller l'argent des contribuables reste inerte devant ce projet humanitaire qui ne coûte rien a a ville. (6 avril 1904).
La Commission adopte un tarif des voitures, mais la Délégation le jette au panier. (6 avril 1904).

La Commission, à la suite d'une interpellation do M. Zouro, charge l'Administration de mettre à exécution sa précédente décision an sujet des repères ; pour la vingtième fois le pouvoir exécutif fait la sourde oreille. (6 avril 1904).
Le 4 mai, nouvelle décision do la Commission au sujet du tarif des voitures et même inertie de la part de la Délégation.

A la suite de nombreux écroulements, la Commission invite l'Administration à présenter, dans la quinzaine, un projet d arrêté provisoire en exécution de l’art. 15 parag. 8 du décret organique. Cette décision reste encore lettre morte. (4 mai 1904).

Pour sauvegarder la sécurité publique de plus en plus compromise avec l’augmentation des moyens do transport, la Commission recommande l’observation des règlements sur les automobiles. A voir celles ci déboucher comme autant, de trombes a tous les tournants de rues, on né peut admettre que ce vote ait été pris en considération. (25 mai 1904).
La question de l’asphaltage des trottoirs est renvoyée à la Délégation aveo le résultat qu on peut deviner. (8 juin 1904).

A l’occasion de la nomination d’un ingénieur, MM. Escoffier et Saïd Bey réclament la mise au concours, qui est votée ; cela n'a pas empêché la Délégation de nommer un candidat de son choix sans donner suite au concours. (22 juin 1904).
Un crédit est ouvert par la Commission pour la confection de plaques portant tarif pour les voitures. Nous les attendons encore. (22 juin 1904).

Dans la même séance, la Commission donne la présidence à M. Zouro, en l’absence de M. Ralli. Comme. M. Zouro est pour elle un gêneur, la Délégation suspend les convocations de la Commission pendant près de 3 mois, jusqu’au retour de M. Ralli, à la fin d’octobre
La Commission vote le prompt lotissement des biens libres, en particulier des terrains du-quai. Mais, la Délégation n’étant pas aussi pressée, rien n’est encore fait. (29 juin 1904).
M. Escoffier se plaint de la qualité de l’eau fournie à la ville et a la Banlieue do Ramleh. La question est renvoyée à la Délégation, ce qui veut dire quelle est classée. (17 octobre 1904).
La question des habitations à bon marché est renvoyée a la Délégation, c'est-à-dire aux calendes grecques. (2 novembre 1904).

M. Zouro demande que la Compagnie des Eaux fournisse l’eau à la ville à robinet libre et a un prix forfaitaire. Cette mesure per mettrait d’employer l’eau sans parcimonie pour les besoins publics, ce qui ne pourrait qu’être avantageux au point de vue de l’hygiène et de la propreté de la ville. Avec le système actuel des compteurs, l'eau, malgré son abondance, est servie avec mesure et l’on n'est pas sûr avec cela que la fourniture soit enregistrée avec exactitude. Il n’en coûterait cependant point à la Compagnie do livrer a la consommation une quantité un peu plus grande que celle qu'actuellement elle fournit La motion de.M. Zouro, appuyée par plusieurs de ses collègues, est renvoyée à la Délégation — qui a sans doute d’autres préoccupations. (28 décembre 1904).
Une foule d’autres décisions tout aussi importantes ont été négligées par U Délégation ; de ce nombre sont le tarif de U Cie de

Ramleh, la contrôle des pouls mesures, etc. etc. Le temps et l’espace nous manquent pour les énumérer toutes. Celles que nous avons citées suffisent d'ailleurs amplement pour montrer le peu de cas que les membres de La Délégation font de leurs collègues de la Commission.
Dans ces conditions on peut se demander comment la Délégation, on dédaignant ainsi les volontés de nos édiles, reste cependant leur mandataire.
C’est une question que nous étudierons dans un prochain article.

div.head: CHRONIQUE JUDICIARE
div.p: SEQUESTRE DES WAKES IBRAHIM PACHA

Cheikh Mohamed Saïd Pacha, agissant tant eu son nom personnel qu’en sa qualité do bénéficiaire des Wakfs do feu Ibrahim Pacha El-Kebir et do nazir et unique bénéficiaire du Wakf de son père, feu Mahmoud Pacha Soliman, a assigné devant le Tribunal des Référés pour l’audience d’hier matin tous les intéressés dans les biens des Wakfs Ibrahim Pacha El-Kebir et des Wakfs respectifs des Cheiks Ahmed et. Mohamed Soliman Pacha, ainsi que dans les biens libres non constitués en wakf, à l’effet d’entendre nommer un séquestre pour la gestion de ces biens, tous en état d’indivision et formant la Daïra de Cheikh Ibrahim Pacha

Mes Lebsohn et Hélou, au nom de Cheikh Saïd Pacha, ont soutenu que les wakfs de Cheikh Ibrahim Pacha Bout, depuis le décès de Cheikh Mahmoud Pacha, dépourvus de la ges tion d’un nazir et que les biens libres font l’objet d’une demande en partage. La désignation d’un nazir par les Mehkémehs et la réali tion du partage devant durer un temps assez long, ils considèrent qu’il y a urgence de pour voir de suite à une gestion provisoire des biens communs. Les dissentiments surgis entre tous les intéressés rendent toute gestion commune et toute entente impossibles.
Me Orfali, dans l’intérêt d'Hassan Hassan Pacha et des fils mineurs de feu Cheikh Aly Hassan Pacha, s'est rallié à cette mesure con servatoire.
Me Mélétios, au nom de la Dame Sékina, sœur do Cheikh Mohamed Seid Pacha, s’est jointe aux conclusions de ce dernier.

Me Colucci conteste l’urgence qui doit seule motiver la recevabilité par le Tribunal, des Référés d’une demande en nomination d’un séquestre. Il dénie en outre aux Cheiks Mohamed Seid Pacha, Hassan Pacha et aux fils de feu Cheikh Aly Pacha la qualité de bénéficiaires des Wakfs de feu Ibrahim Pacha.
Le Tribunal rendra son ordonnance plus tard.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN SALT & SODA COMPANY LIMITED.
div.p: NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that an Extraordinary General Meeting of the above named Company will be held at the National Bank of Egypt in, Cairo on Saturday the 11th day of March next, at noon, for the purpose of considering and if thought fit passing the subjoined Resolution that is to say “That Clause 54 of the Articles of Association of the Company be altered by adding at the end thereof the words for is ratified by an Extraordinary Resolution passed at a separate General Meeting of the holders of the shares of that class and all the provisions hereinafter contained as to general meetings shall mutatis mutandis apply to every such meeting but so that the quorum thereof shall be members holding or representing by proxy one tenth of the nominal amount of the issued shares of the class.' ”Should the above Resolution be passed by the requisite majority it will be submitted for confirmation as a Special Resolution to a further Extraordinary General Meeting.
Dated the 27th day of February 1905.
By order of the Board.
Alfred Lambart,
Secretary to the Board.

Shareholders holding Share Warrants to Bearer who wish to attend the above meeting must first deposit their Bearer Warrants together with a statement of their names and addresses with the National Bank of Egypt either in Cairo or Alexandria two clear days before the date of Meeting (viz : not later than the 8th day of March), the Share Warrants remaining so deposited until after the Meeting shall have been held. Each Depositor will receive a certificate of deposit in exchange for the Share Warrants deposited and a ticket of admission (which must be produced by the holder attending the Meeting) and a form of proxy. If the depositor does not intend personally to attend the Meeting, a form of proxy in favor of the person producing the certificate must bo lodged with the National Bank of Egypt in Cairo or Alexandria not less than 48 hours before the Meeting.

A form of Proxy in favor of the Directors will bo sent to each registered Shareholder. Shareholders who are unable to attend personally are requested to sign and return a form of proxy so as to reach the Chairman at least 48 hours before the Meeting

div.head: Municipalité d'Alexandrie
div.p: AVIS
La-Municipalité procédera le 4 Avril prochain à l'adjudication pour la fourniture d'an rouleau compresseur à vapeur.
Le cautionnement est fixé à L.E 100.
L’offre devra indiquer le type offert, son poids en ordre de Marche, le delai maximum pour la livraison, ainsi que tous au-très renseignements qui s’y réfèrent.
Le montage est à la charge de l'adjudicataire et la consignation sera faite libre de tons frais au Dépôt de La Voirie sis à la rue du 1er Khédive.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté a Monsieur l'Administrateur do la Municipalité avant le 4 Avril prochain.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5hp.m.
L'enveloppe devra eu outre porter la mention: “Soumission pour la fourniture d'un rouleau compresseur.”
Le cautionnement ou le reçu d’une banque devra être remis au Service de la Comptabilité avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 4 Avril à midi.
L'Administrateur,
(Signé) W. P. Chataway
Alexandrie le 25 février 1905.

div.head: The Railway Commission
div.p: TEXT OF THE REPORT.
The following is the text of the report of Lord Farrer’s Railway Commission :—
We have the honor to submit for the information of the Egyptian Government our Report upon the matters referred to us in the Memo randum of the Financial Adviser under date of August 31st, 1904.
The terms of that reference were as follows:—

I. To enquire into the Administration, as it at present exists, with special reference to (a) General Management; ( b) Traffic Management ; (c) Auditing and Accounts, and to make such recommendations with regard either to system or to personnel as may appear to you desirable.

II. To-indicate the manner in which the Capital sum at the disposal of the Government may most advantageously be applied, (a) In bringing the existing system up to date and providing the rolling stock necessary to enable it to cope with the rapidly increasing demands of the public; (b) In the construction of new connecting lines.
III.. As to the advisability of broadening the gauge on the line from Luxor to Assouan.

IV. Whether the arrangement by which the Administration of the Railways has been combined with that of the Port of Alexandria should now be modified, with any suggestions for facilitating the commercial facilities of the Port.

As the reference to us was couched in these somewhat general terms, we have, during our stay in Egypt, taken such steps as we could to make ourselves acquainted, firstly, with the actual operation of the Government Railways as they exist. For this purpose we have travelled over every section of the State Lines open for public traffic ; we have visited all the principal stations ; we have had the advantage of meeting frequently not only the Members of the Board of Administration, but the Chief Officers engaged in working the traffic, and Other Departmental Officers, and we have inspected the principal Workshops of the Locomotive and other Departments, and have visited the Port and Quays of Alexandria.

Secondly, we have had the pleasure of discussing with various Officers of the Govern ment and others acquainted with Egypt, the methods of administration which have hitherto been forced upon the Government Railways, by the necessity of adhering to the terms of International Treaties, whereby the Railways have had to be worked at a fixed percentage of receipts, and have practically been subject to many conditions alien to the ordinary business of transportation, differing indeed from those of any other State or private railway with which we are acquainted.

In regard to point 1 (a) of our reference, viz : General Management, we are unanimous in our opinion that the existing scheme of organisation is unsatisfactory, and that the present opportunity should be taken to remodel it.

The nominal control of the State Railways of Egypt rests in a Board of three persons whose functions are not specially defined. They have neither the initiative which a commercial Board possess, since they cannot raise Capital, nor the responsibility, as they have no shareholders to consider. Nor are they in an ordinary sense members of a Government Department, since all the profits which they may show have not hitherto been directly received by the State.

The functions of the Board appear to be limited to the control of the operating staff, and to seeing that the Railways are worked at an agreed percentage, which has varied at different times from 33 to 54 per cent. They have also to control the Port of Alexandria and the Telegraphs.

It is enough to point out that the system of working at a percentage has proved so unsatisfactory that it has had to be twice changed, simply because, had it not been changed and supplemented by special grants, the Railway must have fallen into ruin. It puts any Board which have to administer it into a false position, because they cannot try any experiments, and often cannot face even necessary requirements for fear of falling below the Budget estimate, and though in many cases it might be profitable to run more trains or to lower rates, the Board cannot do it, because the particular percentage of profit might be only 20 or 30 per cent, instead of the definite figure to which they are bound. In a word it has not been possible to work these railways on good commercial lines, and the want of elasticity and initiative thug necessarily enforced has reflected itself throughout the Administration. It is heartbreaking for officers to know that they cannot get useful sug-
gestions carried through, or real economies effected, because of the iron chain of the per centage arrangement.

But the strongest argument which we can adduce is that of practice. A capital account has already forced itself upon the State for the acquisition of the Port Said and Assouan Lines, and, in our opinion, the time has come for capitalising the value of the State Railways as a whole; and using the figure of nominal dividend upon such sum as the test of management, and thereby introducing a more com mercial system into these Government Rail ways.

It would in our opinion be convenient that the same percentage should be adopted for old and new Capital on the State Railway, and we suggest 5 per cent as a fair figure which, tak ing the Net Revenue of 1903, viz., L.E. 1,063,793, as the basis, would put the present value of the lines open at about L.E.21.275,000. This would make the accounts complete, would give the Executive a fair figure to work to,and would simplify the consideration of new works and extensions.

Following upon this change, and in order to work the system on modern commercial lines, we think that one chief for the whole State Railway system should be appointed, having powers analogous to those of a Managing Director or General Manager in other countries, responsible for the State Railways and Telegraphs, — and the Railways and Telegraphs alone,—iu ail their branches, to a State Council.
DUTIES OF COUNCIL
Such State Council should be formed of at least five Members, who might take general cognisance of all other transport agencies in the country.

The functions of such a Council should not be to interfere directly with the Executive, but to sanction expenditure, and to receive reports of the results of such expenditure,—in fact to be the watch dog of the Government vis-a-vis the Railways and other transport agencies.

The Council need not have frequent meetings, but merely enough to see that publicity in such matters as reports on accidents, or other questions of general interest in regard to the Railways, was enforced, and if necessary to discuss matters of policy with the Chief Officer.
Duties of General Manager.

It would be the duty of the Chief Officer to see that a proper return for the capital expended and to be expended was ensured, to supervise the whole of the executive staff, and to make recommendations with regard to new times.
(To be continued).

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves for the responsible opinions by responsible opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all to permit - within certain necessary limits- free discussion.

div.head: MISSIONS TO MOHAMEDANS.
div.p: To the Editor of The “ Egyptian Gazette."

Sir,—I quite agree with Mr. Maclnnes that a correspondence between us on the subject of religious belief in the columns of the “Gazette," even if admitted, would not be productive of good results. I never knew of any public discussion of religion that did serve a useful purpose, and have not the least wish to enter into one. But if Mr. Maclnnes would discuss such question as the right of private judgment, I should be very pleased to argue it, and defend its exercise in all matters, religious, social, moral or political. The whole is greater than the part, and if man is competent to exercise his judgment on one point he is on all. That would be the base of my argument, and a tolerably firm one I think it is.
Permit me just to call your readers’ attention to the following extract from a London paper which appeared in your columns on Thursday last :

"To the rank and file of Christianity it would perhaps be a waste of time to attempt to teach the lesson that the differences between Islam and Christianity are in reality differences of degree rather than of kind, and not so very much greater, if they are greater at all, than differences between the extreme sects of our own faith.” (The italics are mine). —I am, & c.,
Thos. Atwood.
Alexandria, February 27.
To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette.

Sir,—In a previous letter I offered to tell anyone, who cared to write and ask me, about some results of mission work in Egypt Mr Atwood has not written to ask about results, but does not hesitate to publish publicly, in your issue of 25th, hints (some would call them charges) that an English clergyman, in order to obtain those results, uses “methods that will not always bear the light” I therefore substitute, for my former suggestion, an invitation to Mr. Atwood to come and investigate the methods for himself ; he may then incidentally see some of the results as well. I will give him every facility for the fullest investigation, and such accommodation and hospitality as I can offer while he is in Cairo.— I am etc.,
R. MacInnes,
Cairo, February 27.

div.head: PLOUGHING TRIALS AT SHOUBRA.
div.p: The ploughing trials on Nubar Pasha’s estates at Shoubra on Friday last attracted a considerable number of interested spectators, though the attendance was not so large as would doubtless have been the case had more notice been possible. There was nothing in the nature of a competitive trial, the various machines simply working as the owners pleased in various parts of the ground. Nubar Pasha’s engine, which is a monument of perseverance and ingenuity, was doing good work. Messrs. Aveling & Porter had a large traction engine hauling a cultivator behind, and Messrs. John Fowler & Co. a small compound traction engine hauling a balance plough, and a second engine with a cultivator. The Darby digger was shown in operation, and the Cooper digger was also attracting attention. The American engine hauling a couple of foar-furrow ploughs was a source of interest, but the general opinion was that it was much too liable to breakdowns to be of much utility in native hands. Messrs. Maclaren & Co., of Leeds, showed a ploughing tackle on the double engine system working a cultivator, which was examined with attention by many spectators until an accident occurred, which might easily have had fatal results, as the cultivator, on which two men were sitting, suddenly capsized in full career, fortunately throwing one man clear, but turning over on the other. Happily the engines were stopped at once, or the unfortunate man must have been seriously injured or possibly killed. The cultivator was righted and the bent portions removed, and it was ultimately got to work again, but the public evidently considered after such a performance that it was best watched from a distance.

div.head: Municipalité d’Alexandrie
div.p: AVIS
La Municipalité met en adjudication l’impression des procès-verbaux des séances de la Commission, de la Délégation et autres imprimés en arabe pour la durée de trois ans a partir du 1er Avril 1905.
Le cautionnement est fixé L.E. 15.
Le cahier des charges est déposé au bureau de la Comptabilité Générale où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi,les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l’Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 14 Mars 1905.
Elles pourront également. être déposées en séance de la Délégation le meme jour à 5h. p.m.
L’enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention : “Soumission pour impression arabe des procès-verbaux de la Délégation, Commission et autres”.
Le cautionnement ou le reçu d’une Banque, d’après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis à la Comptabilité Générale avant l’ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 14 mars à midi.
L'Administrateur,
(Signé) W. P. Chataway Alexandrie, le 25 février 1905. 25497-3-1

div.head: Egyptian Delta Light Railways Co., Limited.
div.p: Connections made with the most important trains of the State Railway in the Provinces of Behera, Gharbieh, Dakahlieh Charkieh and Galioubieh.Through service for goods between all stations of the Company andover 100 principal stations of the State Railway in Upper and Lower Egypt. Goods may also be through-booked from or to any station on Helouan Railway. The Company has 70 stations opened for public Telegraph Service in conjunction with all offices of the Government Telegraph Department.For time tables, tariffs and information apply to the offices at Cairo, Alexandria Damanhour, Tantah or Zagazig. 21416 31-12.905
